'''John Samuel Waters''' (born April 22, 1946) is an [[United States|American]] [[Film director|filmmaker]], [[actor]], [[writer]], [[journalist]], [[visual artist]], and [[art collector]], who rose to fame in the early 1970s for his [[transgressive art|transgressive]] [[cult film]]s. Waters's 1970s and early '80s [[trash film]]s feature his regular troupe of actors known as [[Dreamlanders]]âamong them [[Divine (actor)|Divine]], [[Mink Stole]], [[David Lochary]], [[Mary Vivian Pearce]], and [[Edith Massey]]. Starting with ''[[Desperate Living]]'' (1977), Waters began casting real-life convicted criminals ([[Liz Renay]], [[Patricia Hearst]]) and infamous people ([[Traci Lords]], a former [[porn]] star).
Waters skirted mainstream filmmaking with ''[[Hairspray (1988 film)|Hairspray]]'' (1988), which introduced [[Ricki Lake]] and earned a modest gross of $8 million domestically. In 2002, ''Hairspray'' was adapted to a long-running [[Hairspray (musical)|Broadway musical]], which itself was adapted to a hit [[Hairspray (2007 film)|musical film]] which earned more than $200 million worldwide. After the crossover success of the original film version of ''Hairspray'', Waters's films began featuring familiar actors and celebrities such as [[Johnny Depp]], [[Edward Furlong]], [[Melanie Griffith]], [[Chris Isaak]], [[Johnny Knoxville]], [[Martha Plimpton]], [[Christina Ricci]], [[Lili Taylor]], [[Kathleen Turner]], and [[Tracey Ullman]].
